pull.title: Support -checkmempool=N, which runs checks once every N transactions

events.body: What is the behaviour currently?  How often does a sanity check run right now?

Right now runs for every transaction if -checkmempool is specified,
otherwise never.

So the behaviour for =0 and =1 remains the same, but higher number can be
used for lower test frequency.

Nice.
utACK (code review).

_Travis issue is unrelated._
ACK.  Looks like travis needs to be bumped?

events.message: Support -checkmempool=N, which runs checks on average once every N transactions

issue.title: Make -checkmempool=1 not fail through int32 overflow
issue.body: Fix a bug in #6776 discovered by @gmaxwell: -checkmempool=1 causes the internal 32-bit variable to overflow to zero.

events.body: This has a bug: -checkmempool=1 never checks due to integer overflow in the nCheckFrequency= dFrequency*4294967296 and nCheckFrequency is uint32_t, so the result ends up 0.

issue.title: Mempool improvements, branch ID awareness
issue.body:
Whenever the local chain tip is updated, transactions in the mempool which commit to an
unmineable branch ID (for example, just before a network upgrade activates, where the
next block will have a different branch ID) will be removed.

Includes commits cherry-picked from the following upstream PRs:

- bitcoin/bitcoin#6654
  - Only the mempool index change.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6776
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7020
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6915

Part of #2074.

milestone.title: v1.0.15
milestone.description: The Overwinter consensus logic, and a testnet activation height.

issue.title: [Core] MemPool package tracking and limits
issue.body:
built on top of
- [x] #1645 

This PR pulls some updates from upstream in the mempool area, adding the required adjustments for legacy zerocoin txes and updating the functional test suite.

Specifically, here we:
- track mempool descendants (in-mempool transactions that depend on other mempool transactions)
- turn `mapTx` into a `boost::multi_index_container` that sorts the mempool on 3 criteria:
  - transaction hash
  - fee rate
  - time in the mempool
- Add a max size for the mempool (throwing away the cheapest txs and bumping the min relay fee, when full)
- Implement on-the-fly mempool size limit with the flag `-maxmempool`
- Implement `-checkmempool=N` to customize the frequency of the mempool check
- Implement helper for `CTxMemPoolEntry` for the unit tests.

Backports:

- bitcoin/bitcoin#6654
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6722 [`*`] 
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6889
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6771
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6776
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6896
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7020

[`*`] excluding https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6722/commits/9e93640be6c49fa1505ba5c5df8c89210da5a6e4 as our default minimum tx fee rate of 10k satoshis is only 0,00003 USD at the time of writing.

issue.title: refactor: CTxMempool constructor clean up
issue.body:
This PR cleans up the CTxMemPool interface by including the ratio used to determine when a mempool sanity check should run in the constructor of CTxMempool instead of using nCheckFrequency which required a cast from a double to a uint32_t. Since nCheckFrequency (now called m_check_ratio) is set in the constructor and only every read from there after, it can be turned into a const and no longer needs to be guarded by the 'cs' lock. 

Since nCheckFrequency/m_check_ratio no longer needs to lock the 'cs' mutux, mutex lock line in the "CTxMempool::check" function can be moved below where the m_check_ratio variable is checked. Since the variable is 0 by default (meaning that "CTxMempool::check" will most likely not run its logic) this saves us from unnecessarily grabbing the lock.

comments.body: I feel like this would be clearer as two (or at least one) `if` conditionals.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -553,7 +553,10 @@ void CTxMemPool::clear()
 
 void CTxMemPool::check(const CCoinsViewCache *pcoins) const
 {
-    if (!fSanityCheck)
+    if (nCheckFrequency == 0)
+        return;
+
+    if (insecure_rand() >= nCheckFrequency)

comments.body: Not sure: but would't it be more clean to use `ULONG_MAX` here? Also not sure: if using `4294967296` instead of `4294967295`(= ULONG_MAX) wouldn't this result in autocast to `uint64_t`?
Note the .0, making it a double constant rather than an int.

Also, ULONG_MAX gives the maximum value of an unsigned long. Here we need
the number of possible values in a uint32_t. That is by definition 2^32.

 {
-    if (!fSanityCheck)
+    if (nCheckFrequency == 0)
+        return;
+
+    if (insecure_rand() >= nCheckFrequency)

comments.body: IMHO this value should've taken a small comment :).
